description.narrative: The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAPII) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania's work for sustainable poverty reduction and the realization of human rights. The broad operations correspond to several of the goals stated in the results strategy for Swedish development cooperation with Tanzania for the period 2013-2019. UNDAPII results are grouped under four inter-related, mutually dependent themes which acknowledge that Inclusive Growth requites a Healthy Nation, which is Resilient to shocks both (natural and man-made) within a context of transparent and accountable Governance. These four thematic areas are divide into 12 outcomes and 39 outputs. Four out of a total of 12 outcomes in UNDAPII are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy namely; (1) good governance and human rights (2) gender; violence against women and children; (3) female participation and political leadership (4) economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and young people as priority target groups. The program also contributes to the UN's focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together about 20 UN agencies' planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore decreases to some extent duplication of work for national partners as well as for UN organizations. The support is earmarked for the four mentioned results areas a short description is provided below: OUTCOME: ECONOMIC GROWTH AND EMPLOYMENT The Outcome Statement: The economy is increasingly transformed for greater pro-poor inclusiveness, competivness and improved opportunities for decent and productive employment. The aim is to promote economic growth which is inclusive, specifically for pro-poor and provides opportunities for decent and productive employment, in particular for women and youth on both mainland and Zanzibar. OUTCOME: DEMOCRATIC GOVERNACE, HUMAN RIGHTS AND GENDER EQUAILTY The Outcome statement: National Governance is more effective, transparent, accountable and inclusive. The aim is to strengthen Parliament, Government, Ministries, MDAs and LGAs (and other stakeholders) capacities to improve good governance, accountability, the rule of law and access to justice and increase respect, protection and fulfilment for human rights, both on mainland and Zanzibar. This is both influencing the normative agenda as well as providing technical assistance, help with policy coordination, planning capacity, skills development etc. OUTCOME: VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND CHILDREN The Outcome statement: Enhanced prevention of and response to violence against women and children. The aim is to intensify efforts to prevent and respond to violence against women across a range of initiatives on both the mainland and Zanzibar. This will be done by encompassing legislative and policy measures, more effective generation and utilisation of data, expansion of social Welfare case management and referrals to other service providers, addressing harmful cultural norms and practices whilst reinforcing positive practices at household and community level. OUTCOME: WOMEN´S POLITICAL PARTICIPATION AND LEADERSHIP The Outcome Statement: Women and Girls increasingly participate in political and public life and are elected to leadership positions. The aim is to support national institutions to promote accountable and transparent governance on both the Mainland and Zanzibar. Initiatives will strengthen the performance of core institutions, enhancing civic participation in policy formulation and public access to information, establishing a robust evidence base for decision making, facilitating compliance with commitments to international human rights norms and standards, and improving access to a more responsive justice system.

The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania's efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction and the implementation of human rights. The broad business corresponds to several of the goals set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy Tanzania 2013-2019. Four out of twelve results areas are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy: good governance / human rights / gender; violence against women and children; female participation and political leadership; as well as economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and adolescents as prioritized target groups, which also reflects well in the areas of support chosen by Sida.
UNDAP II is fully in line with the donors' Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania's National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II is also developed in line with Tanzania's five-year plan 2015/16 - 2020/21 and with global sustainability and development goals. The program contributes to the UN's focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together 20 UN agencies' planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore, to a certain extent, also reduces duplication for national partners as well as UN organizations.
Swedish support will be provided through One UN Fund, in line with Sweden's policy to support a coherent and more effective UN work in the countries (UN reform "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP is the UN-designated UN body that manages the One UN Fund (through the UNDP office in Dar es Salaam and the headquarters in New York), and the UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) UN High Representative in Tanzania, why both of them stand as UN signing of SAA with Sida. In line with Sweden's earnings strategy for Tanzania, the support will not go to UNDAP generally, but as earmarked for the four mentioned results areas.
The funds will be distributed as follows to the following results areas: - Economic growth and employment: SEK 125,000,000 - Good governance and human rights: 82 500 000 SEK - Women's political participation: SEK 50,000,000 - Violence against women and children: 42 500 000 SEK

United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) i Tanzania är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, som bidrag till Tanzanias arbete för hållbar fattigdomsminskning och förverkligandet av mänskliga rättigheter. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mål som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatområden är särskilt relevanta för den svenska strategin: god samhällstyrning/mänskliga rättigheter/gender; våld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillväxt och sysselsättning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade målgrupper vilket också reflekteras väl i de områden för stöd som Sida valt.
UNDAP II är helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II är också utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femårsplan 2015/16 - 2020/21 och med de globala hållbarhets- och utvecklingsmålen. Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus på förbättrade resultat och samstämmighet genom att sammanföra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk för Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar därför i viss utsträckning även dubbelarbete för nationella partner såväl som för FN organisationer.
Det svenska stödet ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i länderna (FN-reformen "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP är det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) FN:s högste representant i Tanzania, varför båda dessa står som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi för Tanzania kommer stödet inte att gå generellt till UNDAP, utan som öronmärkt till de fyra nämnda resultatområdena.
Medlen kommer att fördelas enligt nedan till följande resultatområden: - Ekonomisk tillväxt och anställning: 125 000 000 SEK - God samhällsstyrning och mänskliga rättigheter: 82 500 000 SEK - Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK - Våld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK

sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 1.b - Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.

1.b - Upprätta sunda policyramverk på nationell, regional och internationell nivå på grundval av utvecklingsstrategier som stödjer de fattiga och tar hänsyn till jämställdhetsaspekter, för att stödja ökade investeringar i åtgärder för att avskaffa fattigdom.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

description.narrative:
The UN has played an important role for Tanzania via its normative dialogue over the last year, not the least in relation to the Covid-19 situation in the country via collaboration between many UN agencies. UN Women has shown significant impact on issues related to gender equality, for example Tanzania in 2021 saw the highest level of Government committing to enhance womens Economic Rights and Justice at the Generation Equality Forum held in Paris. President Samia Suluhu Hassan subsequently appointed a task force of 25 members to oversee the implementation of Generation Equality Commitments for both Tanzania Mainland and Zanzibar. The President highlighted the Governments commitments to Generation Equality and UN Womens support in her speech during the launching of the Generation Equality Taskforce on 15th December 2021. UN Women, UNESCO, and UNFPA - together with development partners, CSOs and the international community - also conducted joint strategic policy advocacy for government review of the re-entry policy for pregnant girl children which in 2021 resulted in the Ministry of Education and Vocational Training lifting the ban on pregnant students and adolescent mothers from attending school (Education Circular No. 2 of 2021).
Programmatic result examples captured by reporting and follow-up during the period are summarised below per supported outcome area of the UNDAP II.
Result Examples: Outcome Economic Growth and Employment
•Business environment improved through establishment of online trade and business registration platforms (trade.tanzania.go.tz; start.business.go.tz; tanzania.eregulations.org)
•10 financial service providers supported to deliver financial products that respond to the needs of smallholders, women and youth (e.g. TPB, Equity Bank, CRDB)
•More than 55,000 micro enterprises (57% women) have improved productivity and incomes.
•More than 35,000 people (60% women) have increased access to finance.
Result Examples: Outcome Democratic Governance, Human Rights and Gender Equality
•119 CSOs were supported to engage in annual Parliament-CSO dialogues, parliamentary committees and/or public hearings across a range of issues, including discussions around the Political Parties (Amendment) Bill, the Finance Bill and sectoral budget reviews. 80 percent of sectoral, watchdog and cross-cutting committees of parliament were equipped to undertake detailed review of bills and make evidence-based recommendations, with a 78% cumulative improvement in performance.
•Legal aid services were expanded through a range of measures including the continued role of legal aid coordination mechanisms to reaching out to 30,158 women and children who benefited from legal aid services.
•Increased birth registration across the country with the simplified Birth Registration System for children under five which has extended to 18 regions with more than 5 million children registered and issued with a birth certificate.
•Gender-Responsive Budgeting capacity building to relevant stakeholders have improved capacity to cost, track and report on public resource allocations following the finalisation of guidelines to operationalize the Gender and Development Policy (2016) in Zanzibar, the development of a matrix to track resource allocations across MDAs and LGAs and the set-up of specialised gender statistics units in the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) and Office of the Chief Government Statistician (OCGS).
Result Examples: Outcome Women's Leadership and Political Participation
•Increased female representation at political leadership level; almost 22% women in the cabinet, 5.8% increase in Deputy Ministers and over 30% increase in women Permanent Secretaries or Deputy Permanent Secretaries. (2021 figures, year 2020 as point of comparison)
•Out of 25 elected women Members of Parliament, 19 women (86.3%) had benefited from the aspirants' trainings.
•In collaboration with MOCLA (Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs), comprehensive analysis of responsiveness of selected legislation and related norms and practices was carried out. A gender bench book for judicial officers was finalized and a gender analysis of the customary justice system was completed.
•Capacity of 402 political party leaders (202 women, 200 men) was strengthened.
Result Examples: Outcome Addressing Violence Against Women and Children
•Finalization of the National Anti-FGM Strategy and the revised National Policy and Management Guidelines for Health Sector Prevention and Response to GBV, VAC and FGM.
•The District Case Management Monitoring System was rolled out to an additional 47 LGAs, reaching 112 out of 184 LGAs on mainland (61%), enabling management and monitoring of child protection case data.
•Enhanced capacity to prevent and respond to violence against women and children via i) 983 established parenting groups reaching 22,231 parents/caregivers (around 35% male) with positive parenting to reduce violence against children, ii) a cumulative 4,444 schools in priority districts on mainland and 232 schools in Zanzibar with programming to address violence against children, iii) Happy and Sad feedback boxes enabled schools to identify?at least 211 child protection cases and refer?more serious cases to the formal?child protection system.
•Through scaling up protection services, the number of women and children accessing essential services for experiences of violence has greatly increased: at least 13,300 women and 19,707 children in mainland and 995 women and 4,767 children in Zanzibar.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
